subject: Re: [junit] What's wrong with using inner classes for tests?
msgSnippet: ... Adding to the thread already in progress: Having the testcases in inner classes complicates dependency tracking and can force unnecessary builds. To some
messageBody:
On Wednesday, April 9, 2003, at 10:33 PM, Sandy McArthur wrote:

> Searching the message archive there seems to be three common places to
> put your tests.
>
> 1) Next to the class you are testing but in the same directory.
> 2) Next to the class you are testing but in a different directory.
> 3) In a public static inner class.
>
>> From my current point of view the third option looks the most
> appealing to me but most people seem to recomend the second.
>
> Can anyone give some good reasons to advoid the third choice? I'm all
> too familar with seemingly clever ideas that fail badly when a project
> gets large and would prefer to learn from other people's mistakes.

Adding to the thread already in progress:

Having the testcases in inner classes complicates dependency tracking
and can force unnecessary builds. To some extent, this depends on how
smart the compiler/dependency tracker is. If you have a class which is
reasonably central to your project and you change a separate test file,
then the test file is the only thing that gets rebuilt. If the tests
are in the java file, then other dependent classes may get rebuilt even
if you are only changing the tests (e.g. adding a new testcase). With
the tests in separate files, I can refactor tests without having to
rebuild or even touch the code itself. When I am refactoring tests, I
want to be able to recompile/rerun after every tiny change and
turn-around time is important.

Similarly, version control logs are more clear. I can readily separate
code changes from test changes. Pure refactoring should not change
tests. Test refactoring or coverage improvement should not change code.
All other changes should touch both.

I find that the hit is even larger for documentation generation than
for compiling the code. I prefer to have the docs automatically update
after every code change.

> Thanks in advance.
